educational_objective: Recognize a Reed-Sternberg cell to diagnose Hodgkin lymphoma.
question_text: A 20-year-old woman undergoes an excisional biopsy of a cervical lymph node.A light microscopy view is shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is Hodgkin lymphoma (Option C). This diagnosis is established by lymph node biopsy, which shows characteristic Reed-Sternberg cells. These large cells are usually derived from B lymphocytes and are either multinucleated or have a bilobed nucleus (“owl's eye” appearance; arrow) with prominent eosinophilic inclusion–like nucleoli. The absence of Reed-Sternberg cells has very high negative predictive value for Hodgkin lymphoma.
